message_1: A complex function $f(z)$ is defined by $f(z) = ze^{iz}$. What is the maximum value of $|f(z)|$ on the boundary of the unit disk $|z|=1$?
message_2:
To find the maximum value of $|f(z)|$ on the boundary of the unit disk $|z|=1$, we can use the polar form of complex numbers. Let $z = e^{i\theta}$, where $\theta$ is the argument of $z$ and $0 \leq \theta < 2\pi$. Then, we have:

$$f(z) = ze^{iz} = e^{i\theta}e^{ie^{i\theta}} = e^{i\theta}e^{-\sin(\theta) + i\cos(\theta)}.$$

Now, we compute the magnitude of $f(z)$:

$$|f(z)| = |e^{i\theta}e^{-\sin(\theta) + i\cos(\theta)}| = |e^{i\theta}| \cdot |e^{-\sin(\theta) + i\cos(\theta)}| = 1 \cdot e^{-\sin(\theta)} = e^{-\sin(\theta)}.$$

Since $-1 \leq \sin(\theta) \leq 1$, we have $0 \leq -\sin(\theta) \leq 2$. Thus, the maximum value of $|f(z)|$ on the boundary of the unit disk $|z|=1$ is $e^0 = 1$.
